title: Sajid Javid's budget plan rocked as debt reaches £1.79trillion
text:
Budget woe: Chancellor Sajid Javid suffered a double blow ahead of next month's Budget

Chancellor Sajid Javid suffered a double blow ahead of next month's Budget amid signs a slowdown in the economy is hurting public finances.

The Office for National Statistics said the Government borrowed £40.3billion in the first six months of the year as spending outstripped tax revenues.

That was £7.2billion, or 22 per cent, more than in the same period last year – a sharp deterioration in Britain's financial health.

The national debt is now £1.79trillion – more than £70,000 per household. The figures leave Javid with little to play with in the Budget scheduled for November 6.

In a second blow, a survey by the CBI showed that manufacturers expect orders to fall at the fastest rate in a decade over the next three months due to the slowing global economy and Brexit uncertainty.

Howard Archer, chief economic adviser to the EY Item Club, said the 'dismal' findings show 'the manufacturing sector struggling markedly in the face of soft domestic and foreign demand'.
